text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm wid crostini
Dijonnaise that's right I needed to make
some crostini to go with that duck
rillette you recently saw or hopefully
saw and I also usually garnish with some
Dijon mustard on the side so I thought
to myself if I could get the mustard in
the crostini we could save a whole step
so that's what I was attempting to do
here and for a first try I thought they
came out very well although with some
suggestions for me I'm sure you'll
improve on them but anyway in the
meantime let me show you what I did and
of course like any crostini recipe it
starts with some stale bread so I have a
two-day-old baguette one-day-old is
probably fine you just don't want to use
really fresh bread so I'm going to go
ahead and start slicing this with my
serrated knife it's really the only
appropriate tool for this job as you can
see I'm going to cut them at that
classic 45-degree angle that just makes
the crostini a little longer and because
I'm trying to do a mustard crostini I
decided to make these a little thicker
than usual so usually crostini just made
with oil so you don't have to worry
about the bread getting soggy but since
we are incorporating the mustard I
figured I should make them a little
thicker than usual just in case so
usually I go about 1/4 inch for regular
crostini here I think we're pushing 3/8
so you're going to cut up some bagged
apps and we'll set that aside while we
make what they call in the business a
compound butter so I'm going to take
some high-quality room temperature
unsalted butter and we're going to
season that up a little bit and to that
we're going to add a little bit of
cayenne a little pinch of freshly ground
black pepper and a little pinch of salt
and then it's time to Dijonnaise this up
with a big spoon of Dijon mustard but
wait that's not all we're going to
introduce a second mustard good
old-fashioned American yellow mustard so
we'll also add some of that straight out
the squeeze bottle an official story
here is designs in there for the flavor
and the old mustards in there for the
color in aroma at that point I'm gonna
grab a little spatula and we're going to
smoosh this together now because we got
kind of an oil and water thing going on
here this probably would be better to
mix with a whisk but then it gets all
stuck in the whisk and that's kind of
annoying so since I'm going to use this
little spatula to spread the butter on
the bread anyway I figured I would just
try to mix it with this and it worked so
it's going to take you minutes but as
long as your butter is room temperature
and not too cold and not too stiff you
should be able to mix this fairly easily
ok so I kept at it until I had a
beautifully smooth mixture or at least
smooth enough
so that looks good right there at that
point we're ready to start swiping this
on our bread slices and we're gonna want
to be generous here and you're going to
want to do both sides for sure and like
I said this is the first time I made
these and I thought I was being generous
but I really wasn't I guess because as
you'll see these could have used a
little more fat but anyway we're going
to spread that mustard butter on both
sides of the bread and we'll line them
up on a lined baking sheet and by the
way raise your hand if it totally drives
you crazy that I'm not finishing off a
row before starting another one and if
you do have your hand up I'd like to say
there's all different kinds of order ok
and then once we do have all our bread
spread with that mustard butter or
birdie Janae's if you prefer but anyway
once those are spread with the butter
we're going to go ahead and pop those in
the center of a 350 degree oven for 15
minutes at which point we're going to
pull those out and flip them over
now generally regular crostini would be
getting pretty close in 15 minutes
because it would just be soaked with oil
and/or butter but here because half our
mixture is mustard these going to take
longer to dry out and crisp up so we're
gonna want to flip these over and you
can see what I'm talking about when I
mentioned earlier I thought I was being
generous with the butter but I really
need to put a little more on so I tried
to scrape the bowl and put out any extra
I could but as I'll explain on the blog
I think I'm actually gonna have you
drizzle these a little and then we're
going to pop that back in for another 10
to 15 minutes or until perfectly golden
brown and crisp and when you pull them
out they really should look something
like this and of course if you are gonna
serve them with a pate or a duck
rillette like I am you should probably
let them cool down but man these smells
so good I really want one I wish one
would break that was unfortunate let me
eat that one and here you go a little
flavor for your ear
oh yeah and while it was very delicious
plain it was extraordinary under our
recently produced duck rillette just an
absolutely perfect pairing so the
holidays are right around the corner and
that means entertaining season parties
hors d'oeuvres appetizers you remember
last year so I'm sure you're going to
have things to serve on crostini and if
you do maybe you'll want to give these a
try hey who wants to serve crostini when
you could be serving crostini
Dijonnaise I mean say it a few times I
think it will grow in you okay so I
really hope you give those a try head
over to food wishes comm for all the
ingredient amounts and more info
usual and as always enjoy
